questions.text: A 40-yrs-old male came to the casualty with complaints of lightheadedness, dizziness, slowing of movement and difficulty in balancing ,history of fall and unable to walk in a straight line. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Multiple System Atrophy As the patient is showing an early age of onset , slowing of movement, history of fall, difficulty in balancing (Cerebellar sign), which is suggestive of multi System Atrophy.

Highyeild:

Multiple System Atrophy It is a form of atypical Parkinsonism . It is characterized by olivopontocerebellar atrophy or striatonigral degeneration which consist of parkinsonism, autonomic features and cerebellar signs. It tends to occur at an early age and is rapid in its progression. Multisystem atrophy shows early, prominent autonomic features . Eg.- Orthostatic hypotension Incontinence Other symptoms- Severe hoarse or dysarthric speech Dysphagia Inspiratory stridor Early gait abnormality or poor balance while walking Inappropriate laughing or crying Tremor-minimal Multisystem atrophy shows a poor response to Levodopa. Multisystem atrophy with an autonomic picture is called Shy-Drager syndrome .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. progressive Supra nuclear palsy - ophthalmologic symptoms are absent in our case - so excluded. Progressive Supranuclear palsy is a form of atypical parkinsonism that is characterized by slow ocular saccades , eyelid apraxia, restricted vertical eye movement with particular impairment of downward gaze . Option: C. Motor neuron disease - no upper motor neuron symptoms like spasticity mentioned in question. Motor neuron disease is characterized by upper motor neuron symptoms and lower motor neuron e.g., Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

Extraedge:

Hot cross bun sign: This is seen in MultiSystem Atrophy/Shy Drager Syndrome (MSA). The ‘hot cross bun’ sign refers to the MRI appearance of the pons when T2 hyperintensity forms a cross on axial images, representing selective degeneration of transverse pontocerebellar tracts and median pontine raphe nuclei .

questions.text: A 62-year-old female came with h/o of fall and experienced hyperextension of neck, restriction of eye movements with impairment of downward gaze. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP) As the patient has axial rigidity, restriction of eye movements with impairment of downward gaze.

Highyeild:

Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP) It is a form of atypical parkinsonism that is characterized by slow ocular saccades , eyelid apraxia , restricted vertical eye movement with particular impairment of downward gaze . Other features- Axial rigidity Reduced blink rate / Poker face Raised eyebrow Postural instability and falls in the first year of diagnosis . Dementia-Executive function dysfunction . Hummingbird sign is seen on MRI. The atrophy of the midbrain results in a profile of the brainstem (in the sagittal plane) in which the preserved pons forms the body of the bird, and the atrophic midbrain the head, with beak extending anteriorly towards the optic chiasma. Midbrain atrophy is best confirmed with reduction in the midbrain to pons ratio.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Multiple System Atrophy which consist of parkinsonism, autonomic features and cerebellar signs which are not provided here. Option: C. CBD-CorticoBasal Degeneration is the least common of the three atypical parkinsonisms and usually presents with asymmetric dystonic contractions and clumsiness of one hand coupled with cortical sensory disturbances manifest as apraxia, agnosia, focal limb myoclonus, or alien limb phenomenon (where the limb assumes a position in space without the patient being aware of the position or recognizing that the limb belongs to him/her). Dementia may occur at any stage of the disease Option: D. Drug Induced Parkinsonism- history of drugs causing parkinsonism eg. Metoclopramide not provided.

questions.text: A 18-year-old male complains of difficulty in bending arms and legs, with movement and postural disorder. You advised him with treatment of Levodopa and the symptoms improved. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dopa responsive Dystonia As a patient’s age is 20 years, she has symptoms suggestive of parkinsonism which is responding to levodopa treatment.

Highyeild:

Dopa-Responsive Dystonia A condition that results from a mutation in the GTP-Cyclohydrolase 1 gene, which can lead to a defect in a cofactor fo r tyrosine hydroxylase and the impaired manufacture of dopa and dopamine. While it typically presents as dystonia , it can present as a biochemically based form of parkinsonism (due to reduced synthesis of dopamine) which closely resembles PD and responds to levodopa, but is not associated with abnormalities on fluoro-dopa positron emission tomography (FD-PET) nor neurodegeneration . This diagnosis should be considered in individuals aged 20 years who present with a clinical picture resembling PD.

Her speech has become monotone, slurred, and slow. On examination, she has dystonic posturing of the right arm with increased rigidity and bradykinesia. There is also intermittent myoclonus when the right arm is held up. When speaking, the patient’s right arm will seemingly rise on its own accord, and she will use the left arm to pull it back down. Her family feels that she often neglects the right side of her body. The patient’s MRI is shown in the figure below. Which of the following is typical of this diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tau deposition Patient is suffering from CBD-CorticoBasal Degeneration which is Tau pathy. As she has rigidity and bradykinesia suggesting parkinsonism. With intermittent jerks (asymmetric dystonic contraction) Intermittent myoclonus Agnosia (neglects right side of body) Apraxia (speech has become monotone, slurred, and slow ) Alien hand phenomenon (right arm will seemingly rise on its own accord, and she will use the left arm to pull it back down) These features are typical findings of CBD-CorticoBasal Degeneration MRI shows asymmetrical,parietal lobe atrophy.

Highyeild:

CBD-Cortico Basal Degeneration is the least common of the three atypical parkinsonisms and usually presents with asymmetric dystonic contractions and clumsiness of one hand coupled with cortical sensory disturbances manifest as apraxia, agnosia, focal limb myoclonus, or alien limb phenomenon (where the limb assumes a position in space without the patient being aware of the position or recognizing that the limb belongs to him/her). Dementia may occur at any stage of the disease.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Alpha-synuclein deposition is commonly associated with multiple system atrophy (MSA), idiopathic PD, and dementia with Lewy bodies but not with Corticobasal degeneration. Option: C. Prominent hallucinations- are found in dementia with Lewy bodies. Option: D. Autonomic dysfunction- is found in Multisystem atrophy.

Extraedge:

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman presents with frequent falls for 1 year. Each fall is preceded by lightheadedness upon standing and walking. Cardiac etiology was ruled out. On examination, she has masked facies, stuttering speech, hypophonia, and a mixed resting and action tremor in both hands. Her strength is normal, but her legs are discolored with mild peripheral edema. Her magnetic resonance image is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Multisystem atrophy Patient has Masked Facies suggesting parkinsonism. With early autonomic symptoms (seen in MSA), Discolouration of legs Lightheadedness and frequent fall(orthostatic hypotension) Tremor and hypophonia (seen in MSA) MRI shows a hot cross bun sign which confirms Multisystem atrophy (MSA)

Highyeild:

Multiple System Atrophy - It is a form of Atypical Parkinsonism . It is characterized by Olivopontocerebellar atrophy or striatonigral degeneration, which consist of parkinsonism, autonomic features and cerebellar signs. It tends to occur at an early age and is rapid in progression. Multisystem atrophy shows early,prominent autonomic features . E,G.- Orthostatic hypotension Incontinence Other symptoms- Severe hoarse/dysarthric speech Dysphagia Inspiratory stridor Early gait abnormality/poor balance while walking Inappropriate laughing /crying Tremor-minimal Multisystem atrophy shows poor response to Levodopa. Multisystem atrophy with an autonomic picture is called Shy-drager syndrome . Hot cross bun sign - This is seen in MultiSystem Atrophy/Shy Drager Syndrome (MSA) The hot cross bun sign refers to the MRI appearance of the pons when T2 hyperintensity forms a cross on axial images, representing selective degeneration of transverse pontocerebellar tracts and median pontine raphe nuclei .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Given the features of parkinsonism on examination and the delay in syncope , dehydration is much less likely, as this typically presents with orthostasis immediately upon standing. Option: B. LEMS is a paraneoplastic phenomenon usually associated with small cell lung cancer associated with weakness and autonomic dysfunction. Option: D. Amyloidosis is typically associated with a small fiber peripheral neuropathy, autonomic dysfunction, and even multiorgan system involvement from amyloid deposition, but parkinsonism is not a typical feature.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with a 1-year history of frequent falls, most of which have resulted in injuries. Although he denies tremor, he does endorse more shuffling in his gait, hypophonia, and diplopia with difficulty walking down stairs. On examination he has a slightly hyperextended neck with slowing of vertical saccades, limited vertical gaze, and lack of convergence. Rigidity is more prominent in the axial musculature than in the upper extremities. MRI is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Progressive supranuclear palsy Patient is suffering from Progressive supranuclear palsy As he has shuffling gait Hypophonia (parkinsonism) Hyperextended neck, rigidity in axial musculature ( central rigidity-Atypical parkinsonism) Slow ocular saccade,limited vertical gaze,lack of convergence (progressive supranuclear palsy) MRI shows Hummingbird sign confirming Progressive supranuclear palsy.

Highyeild:

Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP) It is a form of atypical parkinsonism that is characterized by slow ocular saccades , eyelid apraxia , restricted vertical eye movement with particular impairment of downward gaze . Other features- Axial rigidity Reduced blink rate / Poker face Raised eyebrow Postural instability and falls in the first year of diagnosis . Dementia-Executive function dysfunction . Hummingbird sign is seen on MRI.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Idiopathic parkinson disease- will not have early postural instability. Option C. Multisystem atrophy- will have autonomic features. Option D. Normal pressure hydrocephalus- characterized by triad of Dementia, Ataxia, Urinary incontinence.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presented to you with a history of rigidity, tremor and postural instability. On T2 weighted MRI, the following sign was seen. What is your most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MSA -Patient presented with parkinsonism (rigidity,tremor) with early autonomic features (frequent fall) and p utaminal rim sign on T2 with MRI suggests Multiple System Atrophy. Putaminal rim sign. - The putaminal rim sign, also known as the putaminal slit sign , is said to be a relatively specific sign of multiple system atrophy and parkinsonism (MSA-P) , and refers to a linear region of high signal surrounding the lateral aspect of the putamen at 1.5 T MRI on T2 weighted images. -Unfortunately, this appearance can be seen in normal individuals when imaged with a 3T MRI.
